item.title: Activation of @sign
item.description: Next up we need to activate it Login to your dashboard at https://my.atsign.com/dashboard Open ‚Äúmy @signs‚Äù Open ‚Äúmanaged‚Äù of @sign you are registering‚Äù Navigate to Advance settings: If you have already activated your @sign you will be prompted to erase all your data first Once done you are able to link your @sign with your private dess. Use your domain and port number with which you have created service on your cloud instance and press Activate

item.title: Instance setup and dess deployment
item.description: Open your GCP console at https://console.cloud.google.com/compute/instances and search for VM instances By now you should see your instance in ‚ÄúRunning state‚Äù Click on the SSH button and connect to your instance. You should be presented by new window with command line: Before we do anything else, we should update the system: sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade This might take some time, but it will make sure we have latest repository information and the system is up to date.

item.title: Introduction
item.description: dess stands for ‚ÄúDistributed Edge Secondary Server‚Äù and it is used to host your @signs on your own secondary server. Refer to the Setup dess guide under Options to learn more. In this step-by-step guide we will walk you through all steps required to setup your own private dess in GCP cloud from scratch. Please use index to skip some steps in case you have done them in another way.

item.title: Pre-requisites
item.description: Register Atsign at atsign.com Have google account Have registered Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN) 1. Registering your @sign # This topic is already well documented. Please follow the guidance of Our FAQs and register via the registrar site. 2. Sign-up for GCP account # a) Account Creation # If you are new to cloud like me and need to create new GCP account, I have good news! The creation is for free.

item.title: Preparing GCP Instance
item.description: Now since I am new to GCP the easiest way to start using it is with prebuild solutions. This way you will deploy small system which is more then capable of handling dess at pre-set price. We can use pre-build ‚ÄúUbuntu 20‚Äù. In Search bar look for Ubuntu20 üî¥ Make sure to use ‚ÄúUbuntu 20‚Äù and not ‚ÄúHardened Ubuntu 20‚Äù. Although the Hardened version will work as well it requires additional manual steps to make work.

item.title: Preparing your instance for network access
item.description: a) Assignment of Static IP # Next up our list of activities is providing our instance with static IP and linking our domain to it. GCP assigned ephemeral IP address to our newly created VM. We need to change it to static IP. In search bar look for External IP addresses. You should see your external IP address assigned to your VM In column Type select ephemeral and change it to Static

item.title: Registration of @sign in your private dess
item.description: At this step you should already have your @sign registered at atsign.com. If not go do it! I have registered my own free @sign (@44likelycanary) which I will link to my dess. In your instance console, navigate to dess folder. If you were following this guide it will be located in: We now need to create the service that will host our @sign by executing the dess-create command: $ sudo dess-create @44likelycanary 4atsign.
